reviewText: I like these choose-your-own-adventure stories in general, but they have been very hit or miss for me depending on how much the writing disconnects from the choices I make. I don't want to give anything away about the story so I will start with an analogy, *not* an actual example. Imagine you are asked by a story to choose your favorite beverage - water, cola, or liquor. You answer water, only to be told you would have preferred liquor and now you are sad because you wanted to get buzzed. I am? I did?\n\nAgain, trying not to give anything away about the game, but give an *actual* example of what I mean this time ... on my playthrough, the story severely broke down in the end. It was clear that the later elements of the story were written from the perspective of the character struggling against the crisis unfolding, even if your previous choices made it clear you did not view what was happening as a crisis. In other words, I had to choose the same option about six times in a row to get to the next page so the story could tell me how worried I was again, even though I had just chosen not to be worried. To paraphrase the responses ... It's terrible
recommended: you can't believe this happening. Now is the time to act!" Why? I've told you six times I don't care. Next page please ... "OK
voteText: you're distraught
helpfulPercent: you can't believe this is happening." I can't? I have repeatedly told you to let it happen. Please just get on with it! "OK
votesHelpful: but you view your special item as your one hope to stop this terrible
votesFunny: I don't - get on with it! "OK
commentsCount: but ..."\n\nThe result of this defect is that for me
column16: this title wasn't really choose *your* own adventure
column17: more like choose *someone else's* adventure and be told how they feel about it. Therefore
column18: I can't recommend this game based on my experience. I think the reason I don't find this defect in non-text-based games that feature choice is that there is no inner monologue to contradict how you personally feel about the choices. Just something to keep in mind
column19: in case you are thinking of purchasing the game
column20: but would be disappointed by such a disconnect should you deviate from the author's perspective. On the other hand
column21: if you happen to agree with the viewpoint of the author
column22: you would never notice the defect and might really love the story."

reviewText:
You´re appointed as new CEO of the leading firm for Hightech, Witchcraft and Extraterristic science. Now doesn´t that sound just splendid?

Sadly this has to be the first choose your own adventure ebooks, which really fell flat for me in some regards.
The development of your own character skills is at nearly no point an important decision, the only thing that matters is research and the stats of the enterprise. While this may be realistic for a CEO, it is kinda dull and mainly influenced through the budget sessions.

Also the romance part (which for this kind of game should normally offer some options) is a bit lackluster... i kind of got forced into the gay romance line, as he was the only one available.. which didnt matter much anyway in the end.

Regarding the story, it also got somewhat over the top for me, when time travelling became an issue. That´s naturally a very personal taste, but that part just didn´t work out for me.

To round it up, the end game also has some bugs into it, where people appear twice, while they should be actually dead already (mind you, that was also an important part of the ending judgement, so no small lapsus imo).

So, while the writing is mostly ok the overall game just had me dissapointed, especially so, since the premise made me very interested in it.

Conclusio: You surely can get more refined CYoA books by now, so if you´re no hardcore fan of the topic, you can skip this one.

Rating: 5/10

reviewText:
I don't have much experience with these choose your own adventure things, but I've played a few visual novels in my time. All I can say is that this offers a large number of choices in comparison, and these choices have real impact on what happens and what options you have later on. More than your average Telltale Game I would wager. You also have a lot of control over your companies strategy and which augments you develope for profit or your own use (and you WILL use them).

Also, you can enter your own name to be referred to, and pick a gender INCLUDING options for It's complicated but I guess I'll put ___" or "I won't answer this question". Nice touches.

reviewText: This game reminds me of a term from dungeons and dragons called 'rail roading', used to describe gameplay sessions where you only think that you have some agency in deciding your fate as a player but really youre just riding along on a straight line so the dungeon master can show off all the pretty scenery and plot he wrote up.

reviewText:
The good:  Amazingly realized world, great writing.  If you're the kind of person that cares whether a game accomodates non-binary gender pronouns and the like then you'll find they've taken every measure for sensitivity's sake.  The power fantasy of running, lets be honest here Massive Dynamics from Fringe, is great fun.

The Bad:  Unlike most of their games there appears to be one path to win, or at least a narrower set of them than the usual.    At points it becomes less-than-realistic.  There is way more randomness than many Choice of Games entries with your resources which are what determines how much you can do and thus how much you can make.  So a bit of bad luck or one bad decision quickly snowballs into an unwinnable playthrough.

The Bottom Line:  A great game, but not as superlatively awesome as others from this publisher.  The skill development system (which normally is a glorified decision tree system, if you've skilled up in a given area more than X times then you can sweet-talk the guard if not... he kicks your butt) is reused to provide more freeform options.  It's a shame that they never really go anywhere interesting with it because it boils down to have you checked enough boxes to win?"  Relies a bit much on guessing
date: the results of actions are not always logically connected to the input: a fatal flaw in a text-based game like this!  This is especially apparent in the first act.  Also
recommended: a lot of threads like the Romance options seem shoehorned in so they can say "has X romances!" on the promo blurb and have no bearing on gameplay in a significant way.  In one playthrough I was gay
voteText: and the lesbian romance option was slightly more fleshed out (ooh
helpfulPercent: controversial!) because they went on vacation with me.  But beyond a few more scenes and a chance to ♥♥♥♥ off my partner by ignoring her wishes and engaging in corporate skulduggery she asked me not to
votesHelpful: nothing of consequences was gained or loss.\n\nBuy this if you like:  Power fantasies

reviewText:
Fantastic game. Typically, I find stories with this format rather unappealing due to the vast scope of the world and its unnatural setting combined with a familiar story (magic/Aliens - CEO of corporation). Which typically make getting immersed in the story difficult because you are given such a narrow view with which to see what’s going on around you and with so much is going on its easy to get confused or hung up on certain details.

However, that is not a problem with this game you very quickly learn its focus and what you are setting out to achieve which lets you focus on the intrigue of the main story and the satisfaction of seeing your metrics improve month on month make you feel like a real super powered CEO with plenty of scope to be the good guy philanthropist or the brutal cut throat businessman.

I love that fact that you get to play a little allocation of resources game month on month as a method of establishing focus and showing the player the consequences of their actions and I hope to see more of this kind of mechanic in future games.

Simply put I cannot recommend this game enough

reviewText: I've bought pretty much all the games the developers (Choice of Games) have made and released on steam. I really enjoy them, some of the games they release have way too much information on the first couple chapters and sometimes stuff story down your gullet before the real fun part starts. But MetaHuman Inc got very interesting really quick. You become the CEO of a company that creates super powers or enhancements and are able to choose from a range of ways you will manafacture them. I wont go too far into the story, but its very entertaining to be incharge of a large company and becoming a millionare. The story can get a bit much and boring at times but is fairly addicting as you start to have more freedom. I reccomend this game to those who love super powers or a bit of Sci Fi and Mystery to their games.

reviewText:
--------------------Mild Spoilers--------------------

TL;DR; Pros and Cons:

Pros

Good character-development for the main protagonist.
Innovative and interesting concept
Diversity with choices and repurcussions; most-of-the-time listing about 4 - 6 options per screen, with non-superfluous options -- greatly-differing from one another at times, not filler choices.
Innovative Management System
Good writing; however it is not descriptive; at least to what I like to see.
Interesting and deep story

Cons

Lacks solid character development of your co-workers, besides yourself
Alternative ending branches are not well-executed
Lackluster romance-branchs
Not extensively-detailed writing.

8.5/10

MetaHuman Inc. is about taking the role of a CEO of a prodigious company, being in a company that previously did not have legitimate methods of producing their Human Enhancements, (human augmentation,) and at times, having un-ethical ways of dealing with things. MetaHuman Inc. has enhancements such as physical enhancements and psychological enhancements, which you can receive yourself, which aids in a gargantuan way over the course of the game; you do not have to get any augmentations, but it is recommended you receive all of them. Will you continue to spread the corruption and foster the corruption of the company? Perhaps alternatively, do you plan to change it, for the better? Perhaps indefinitely? Will the company crumble, under your tutelage? May it serve as a beacon of what truly embodies an ethical and methodical or a daring, innovative company? Perhaps it may even just end up as another bankrupt company; way past its expiration date. Are you the type to take the fall for your own mistakes, or pin it on others? Are you an unscrupulous, venal and virulent impulsive corporate-overlord, or a sympathetic, cordial, honest and pertinent CEO, or something inbetween? Whom should you confide in, and whom should you be vigilant of? Perhaps even betray others? Will you become a hated person of the press, or a person whom is praised by the press?

MetaHuman has 12 stats in total: the Executive Bio: Leadership, Resolve, Candor:Guile and Compassion:Ruthlessness, Company Profile: Image, Morale and Intimidation, Research Department Profile: Witchery:Superscience and Research Staffing

--Executive Bio—

Leadership is self-explanatory - the ability to lead. However, thematically with leadership, it is also to an applicable extent, how much your co-workers respect you - do they respect your final say? Or alternatively, would they argue and debate what you say right-off-the-bat, provided you have low Leadership. It is also the ability to keep people calm.

Resolve - the ability to follow through with your ambitions and resist and push on through hardships.

Candor is quite simply being honest and open; frankness.

Guile is simplistically how cunning you are - characteristic of a cunning, manipulative and lying CEO.

Candor and Guile are a ratio - when you are open and honest, your Guile decreases, however if you are deceptive and/or you lie, your Candor would decrease, and obviously your Guile will increase.

Compassion is simply if you have a good heart; you're altruistic.

Ruthlessness is the opposite of Compassion - if you do not have a heart and you do not mind firing employees just because they made a mistake, or making somebody 'disappear' because they may of gotten on your nerves or done something wrong, albeit un-fair, that is the natural nature of the Ruthlessness stat.

--Company Profile--

Image is how your company is portrayed, indicative to how you handle the press and the decisions you make. 'Your' business could be loved, despised or be seen as another typical company. Business is also reflective on your image as well; if you have bad business, chances are your image will be afflicted.

Morale is the general-construct of your co-workers' conglomerate dispositions.

Intimidation is how much your co-workers fear being insubordinate; a decent level of intimidation is adequate. It is also the ability to scare other people, simultaneously.

--Research Department Profile--

Head of Department is the person whom runs the Research Department; oversees everything, from development of Enhancements, to general well-being of fellow co-workers. There is 3 choices at the beginning of the game. A person whom specialises in Superscience, a person that is proficient at both, so you can effectively choose if you wish to go with Superscience or Witchery, or lastly, you can choose somebody whom specalises in Witchery.

The simplicity of these stats are sufficient enough, but at the same time, intricate and it tendrils its signifiance, while maintaining transparent simplicity as a stat.

MetaHuman does an exemplary job of capturing the appeal of being a CEO of such a myriad company, with the benefits of a high salary, assets, expensive clothing, influence, and notoriety a respective position would bring. The CEO heavily-entangles himself with all of the interesting affairs of being a CEO of such a large company would entail: the press, distribution of the company's' budget each month, donation to an event-triggered charity, detective work, a company similar to scale with yours, acting as competition, coordinating and/or being in the field with special agents, hunting down mythical creatures, apprehending somebody, or at times, preventing a crisis that could potentially be damaging to your company if you do not handle it correctly, provided it goes wrong.

This fantastic and interesting installment of this multiple-choice-game tackles interesting philosophical questions - questions that can morally leave you absolutely-conflicted; choices that both seem absolutely morally-viable, but one or the other leaving a catastrophic and baleful mark on the world. Finally, what it is like to truly make a difference - good or bad.

MetaHuman Inc. additionally provides some diverse dialogue options and methods of dealing with certain situations: ranging up to 6 options on a solid-basis, which solidly-provides interesting repurcussions, albeit some seem completely-forgotten about -- some.

However, this game is not without its flaws - it has issues. The romance branches seem fairly lackluster, being fairly-simplistic and rudimentary and not having genuine-depth, albeit it being at a 'Satisfactory' level. This game also skims over some decisions, albeit they may not be copious, it still makes a difference, in terms of the competency of a 'multiple-choice-game.' This applies to events that are not necessarily imperative to the story line. It also does not completely do an exemplary job on an alternative ending, rather it gives you an alternative way to replay the game, but in an interesting fashion.

Colloquial Verdict: Overall, this game was a fantastic experience. Fantastic writing, not as descriptive for my liking, but still good, concise writing nonetheless! This game gripped me all the way to the ending, me playing for roughly 4 - 5 hours straight, non-stop, and I recommend this game to almost anybody that is interested in science-fiction, or likes thought-provoking, indelible and interesting games -- a poignant game. I give this game a 8.5/10, for its exemplary-execution of the grand concept, the good writing, the intriguing story. What prevented this game from becoming great (in my opinion) is just some work with some of the alternative endings, and the lackluster romance-branches. Other from that a FANTASTIC game.

reviewText:
Another well done release by Choice of Games.

I probably did not take the most entertaining route but the ending was a big surprise for me considering the choices I made. The story is great, the choices have meaning and I will need to play through again.

It is not all just about making choices though, there is plenty of variability beyond multiple choice answers when you control the company. I gave myself a bit of a streamlined path but I am sure I can twist things up a bit next time around.

Sorry if I am not much of a critic but I can say that there weren't any real negatives for the type of game and I would give it a play through if you like the genre.

reviewText:
MetaHuman Inc is a lot more fun than I even expected. It's essentially the combination of a choose-your-own-adventure novel with RPG elements. I can't wait to play through it again and see how the story develops with other choices, which is exactly the reason CYOA books can be so fun.

These kinds of books and games only work if the story is good, and this one is not only compelling but quite intricate.

My only complaint is staring at a white screen for long periods of time gives me a bit of a headache so I have to take frequent breaks- not a big deal, though.

reviewText:
Like all other Choice of Games games, this one gives you a non-linear story that will be shaped by your choices, for better or worse. This time out, you're thrust into the role of a CEO of a research company dabbling in making humans metahuman - sort of like superpower capitalism, except instead of being a superhero story, it is a cosmic horror story due to the price you have to pay for the research. Nice twist, that.

Unfortunately, like some Choice of Games games, unless you choose a polarized approach and stick to it 95%, you're not getting a decent ending. This makes your first playthrough, the blind one, essentially poking at the game to see what major milestone mistakes you can make, and then prepare for a 'proper' run to see a specific storyline formed by taking a coherent approach.

On the one side, it's a good thing, since this allows multiple reruns of the same game while seeing tons of new non-repeating content. On the other side, like in imperfect gamebooks, you can clearly see where the tracks cross, like here's a dialogue option I would have picked if I picked THAT dialogue option two chapters ago... what I'm more interested in
date: is why there isn't a follow-up to the option I DID pick?".\n\nThe game suffers a bit from what I like to call the "Mass Effect Dialogue Issue": sometimes
recommended: the options you are offered aren't 100% related to what your player character ultimately ends up doing
hoursPlayed: although it has a lot less issues with it than
voteText: say
helpfulPercent: Hero Project. It's also highly unclear at times whether a decision result is calculated based on your stats or RNGed
votesHelpful: a traditional issue of Choice of Games games that messed up my enjoyment of Mecha Ace greatly.\n\nAll in all
votesFunny: it's a nice addition to the collection and a worthy recommendation to anyone
commentsCount: especially since the corporate backstabbing angle is weirdly complemented by the cosmic horror setting
column16: but if you had doubts about these games before
column17: this one will not change your opinion in the slightest.\n\nAlso
column18: if you don't mind me saying this
column19: the ending feels somewhat rushed and disjointed due to the need to tell three outcomes as a singular story
column20: since way more focus is given to what your shareholders think of you rather than what state you leave the world in or what your decisions or indecisions did to the various characters. Yes
column21: this will make the next runthrough as a heartless embezzler easier to do

reviewText: I've played quite a few of these choose-your-own-adventure style text games over the past few days.  They've absorbed many, many hours of my time.  I went into it knowing exactly what it was, and was quite content with what I found.  All of the titles from Choice of Games that I've played have been enjoyable, but Metahuman, Inc. is the best one, in my opinion.  It's much more open-ended than some of the others, with more endings, and it takes a few playthroughs before you really get to know all of the characters.  I really felt like the enhancements add a lot to the game, where your ability to run your research department efficiently and the order in which you develop enhancements opens up new options during conversations and conflicts, and therefore new branches in the story, as well.\n\nTo address something I've seen others saying, I didn't experience much of a disconnect between my choices and the replies.  This one seems to be much, much better about it than at least one of the other titles I've played.  However, I'll admit that there are some endings I haven't pursued.  Perhaps it's not as good with one or two of them.  I don't know.

reviewText: Okay, now before I say anything, this game is pretty much a Choose Your Own Adventure game. K, now while that maybe true, at <5 dollars (<3 in my case) this is a great game. It's pretty simple to be honest, you control a company that makes superpowers. Now while that may not seem like much, the fact that you can use the powers to help you in certain situations and have different responses depending on your stats makes this easily the funnies Choose Your Own Adventure game I've ever played. If you're okay with alot of text and a more laid back gaming experience, this is the game for you!

Two words: BUY IT! (especially if you like sci-fi/mystery genre, or if you like TV series like Heroes for example).

I just finished the story. Very immersive. If you've ever read a book to the late hours of the night from cover to cover, just because it's that good, this is it. But it's a game. And it's a book. I quite don't know what to call it - interactive book" doesn't quite describe it well enough in my opinion. Something in between of a book and a game.

At one point
date: I spend almost 15 minutes on one page
recommended: thinking and trying to decide what to do based on all the information I had at that point
hoursPlayed: my suspicions of what's to come
voteText: all the possible consequences and outcomes of my actions.\n\nStill
helpfulPercent: it's very well written. Nothing is too ovbious
votesHelpful: you can try to guess what will happen
votesTotal: and when you think you do know
votesFunny: it will suprise you.\n\nYou really get the feel that events are happening because of the choices you make. And there was only maybe one or two pages where it felt a bit like I didn't have enough options to choose from
commentsCount: which broke the illusion a bit (for a second).\n\nI will most likely play this through again at some point
column16: just to see how much I can change the events. So
column17: allthough the magic of this game is mostly on first experience
column18:
it does have some replay value also.

I REALLY hope they will make a sequel for this book.

10/10

reviewText: Under normal circumstances I have never read a game to have fun, until now. MetaHuman Inc reminds me of the goosebumps novels that I used to read when I was young offering a plethora of choices as you explore a written adventure. I was hooked from the first few minutes reading the story and found that I was unable to stop playing until finished the adventure. The writing is excellent and the story is great. The author really makes each choice feel real and important and nothing is without consequence. If you like RPG's that show when the results of your decisions then this game is for you. It is a storybook adventure and thus not a traditional game for me. However I was very happy with my purchase.\n\n5/5

reviewText:
First off, this is a text only choose-your-own-adventure, if anyone was unaware. If you value graphics over story or player decisions, this probably isn't the type of game for you.

This is a pretty fantastic entry, which combines compelling storytelling with interesting mechanics and choice that seem to actually matter. I also enjoyed the game testing my own detective skills at a few points, challenging me to solve a mystery with the game only giving me helpful clues for correct choices instead of the direct answer like so many other games do, making it seem challenging without being unfair or obtuse. I felt genuinely immersed when playing this, which seems odd for a cyberpunk-fantasy choose-your-own-adventure, but it was just a very enjoyable experience that I felt a part of.

My main criticism is that some of the decisions, especially the routine ones which you can adjust regularly throughout the game, should have to be confirmed before they are made permanent, as it is easy to make an error if you misclick or misread the option.

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good story or enjoys a game where the player's choices actually matter.

reviewText: Overall a very enjoyable experience. For those who enjoyed the Hero Rise trilogy and Choice of Deathless, I highly recommend this game. The only thing I was unhappy to see was blatant self-promoting of another game, although the game which was promoted was in fact receieved very well by the players.\nThe stats used in this game are delightfully helpful while remaining minimal in the sense that it does not control the overall plot; the plot is still up to you to decide. Furthermore there is a significant replay value and I look forward to unlocking all endings. I recommend this as the best available game by Choice of Games.

Personally I don't hate games like this where you click and decide your fate one slide at a time. But something about this one just really makes me want to gauge my eyes out. I've only spent twelve minutes playing this game and it probably gets more and more interesting as it goes but I personally just can't make it any longer than this.

If they added a more lively taste to the game maybe this would be a good review but I just can't bring myself to keep clicking options of dialogue that just make me want to kill myself after a minute or two.

I'll keep the game in my library to see if anything new comes along that might make it more interesting than it just being a survey to see if your as corrupt as the next guy or not, but I don't have high hopes.

reviewText:
Damned amazing is what I'll say. The story was superb and I'd love to see a movie made using the plot! It's quite interactive. The choices give enough for you to forsee the outcomes, but there's always a murkiness to it to remind you that the future is not as clear as you think. They don't just throw in some outrageous obstacles or interventions(though certain past actions and good planning will certainly help in the long run, so don't be shy with using your resources up).

I've played a few text-based games, but this certainly grabs the top spot for me. The story was certainly unique, developing further and further into the sci-fi/fantasy genre(magic and science are tied together though there isn't exactly an in-depth discussion regarding this. Rather it just exists as it does. Tools of the overall plot). Then at the end comes the twist, with the final conclusion based on the decisions you take at the last pivotal moment.

I just wish there were ways to have more influence on the behaviors and actions of some the close members of the character. Affect them in certain ways that would determine how they'd contribute towards the end, and perhaps affect how well they do their jobs.

If you enjoy ruthless shareholders, running a shady business to glory(or infamy), time travel, magic, science, and the occassional enigmatic alien making suspicious promises...then this is a game for you. Even in it's text based format, it isn't completely sparse of visual aspects(albeit they're colorful bars representing certain business and personal information) nor is it lacking in entertainment and action.

I'm glad to have bought this game, and seriously hope this takes off  to become something greater.

Review:

MetaHuman is unlike any other game I've played before. It is simple to play yet brims with a thick plot waiting to be discovered! You start with an accusation of stealing 2 million dollars and your choices in the next moments determines who you are in the game.  You can choose your background, gender and name. The game even allows for diverse gender roles should you Identify as neither male or female exclusively.  25 minutes into this game I have just finished telling the press about my plans for MetaHuman much to their disapproval.  The Popular Press hates me and my vision but I can say I'm Damn excited to be hated.

Please watch the video above for my first reactions and also examples of the issues i have mentioned so far.

Thanks and have a great day guys!

reviewText: Really enjoyable story - every action you take seems to have a very meaningful impact both in the short and long term. It is very interesting to play with the different leadership styles in the game and see how things play out as a result!\n\nThis is one of the better Choice of Games :)
voteText: 7 of 19 people (37%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game was amazing, plain and simple. Trying to explain the plot is so difficult because of the interwoven themes and genres that baffles me still about how well it works.

Mechanically, I never felt once like my choices were just tossed off and without meaning, just a number that ultimately turns out the same. Every choice had weight. Some choices were difficult. Some were ultimately very satisfying. All were interesting.

That is something -very- hard to pull off these days, but through masterful writing and an impactful story, they have made it real.

All in all, this game is way more than what I had purchased it for. Not just for the fact that I'm probably going to restart the experience anew right after writing this, but for an experience unlike any story I've seen or heard of before. This is a rare gem, and I thank the creator for it graciously.

reviewText:
While not typically my first choice of genre for gaming, I thoroughly enjoyed my time playing this game. I've completed one playthrough, and though I'm unsure as to how much of a difference your choices will impact the game, the first playthrough was well enough worth the price.

I, personally, took the compassionate, candor route, and was mostly please by my choices and the actions instilled within the story-arch because of those qualities. The game itself is an interesting take on balancing a company and staying true to your own identity. Some of the choices you make are quite difficult, as they may be morally sound but bad for the company.

Overall, 8/10 I really enjoyed this game, and would recommend it, especially at the sale price.

reviewText: I'm new to interactive novels and choose-your-own-adventure style text-based games. That said, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with this one. It was surpisingly deep, and the options available to you were clever and astonishingly varied. Many decision-based games have low replay value, but this one seems like it would only deepen given several repeat playthroughs.  I will certainly be trying other games by the same developer.\n\nThere were a few typos, which briefly shook my fervor. A minor quibble in most games, but in a text-based game it's a little more unforgivable.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Cons:

-makes you wish there were more sequels

-makes you wish you had access to supernatural/alien technology

-no checkpointing system

-no relationship system

Pros:

-strong story with in-depth coding to determine type of scenes/options you get – for example, there are 4 requirements you can meet to succeed a certain “check,” and failing to meet any of them will result in an automatic fail

-one of the best-written titles available in the Choice of Games franchise, especially if you enjoy supernatural/sci-fi themes

-interesting and engaging characters

-choices have great impact and directly affect the story and your stats

-stats are very critical for succeeding in checks when given different options – if you try to lie when you’re known to be truthful, you will probably fail

This title is easily one of my top choices for choose-your-own-adventure games, and if you want to be the CEO of a powerful company (that deals with witchcraft and alien technology), then you must give this a try.

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!

Cheers,
DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews
